messageBody:

> regarding problems using JUnit for testing EJBs. My text is marked with my

> DS > Junit internals suck. I would love to rewrite it, but don't

> DS > you misunderstood the comments from other people. JUnit is a good

> DS > of XP development. The problem with XP is that it is not designed for
> DS > Library software (see the last chapter of the xp book), so it works
> good
> DS > at what it was designed for, but it is difficult to expand. They also
> DS > use way too much inheritance and not enough interfaces. Anyway, just
> DS > read the code and be the judge for yourself.


While I wouldn't put it the way that "DS" put it, I do agree with some
of his assertions.

I am constantly trying to figure out what is meant by the difference
between "Test" and "TestSuite". Essentially, the way that the
testrunners work really confuses the issue.

A TestCase is a collection of tests. Each test is run by creating a new
instance of a class and passing in the method name of the "test" being
run. However, in the process the TestCase is then treated like a
TestSuite. Unless a class implements the suite() method, there is no
way to change how test runners will work.

I had to perform such a hack for the Avalon testsuite software. In
that scenario, I had the extended TestCase load the container that the
components run inside of, as well as the support classes and
configuration information. Unfortunately it is not terribly clean as
much reflection based code suffers from that affliction. I would like
to alter the test framework for Avalon to basically have a *tester*
component that would look up the components in question from an existing
container and then run its suite of tests. Unfortunately it doesn't fit
the JUnit framework way of doing things.

To further complicate the matters, there are extension classes in JUnit
that I do not use because I do not really understand what they are for.
I know that JUnit works--which is really cool. However, trying to
figure out *how* it works is a real PITA. It becomes an obstacle when
trying to extend JUnit to work outside the simple case it was designed
for.

While in principle, I am against C#, there are some language constructs
that I find would be really nice in Java--most notably the concept of
Delegates and Attributes. I read an article how it would be easy to
through a more powerful and flexible testing framework together using
those two features. The test runner would collect all the testable
classes by their attributes, and then find out which test to runn on
the methods using delegates: something like the following:

[TestWith(SubtractionTester)]
int subtract( int i1, int i2 )
{
return i1 - i2;
}

That way we can build a library of similar functionality--encouraging
a consistent naming scheme for methods so that you can reuse pre-written
tests. That reduces the amount of similar rework necessary for
different tests.

(in order to get it to happen with JUnit, you would have to use XDoclet
to create your own JavaDoc tags and manufacture your own Delegate style
framework making a more powerful "Method" object).
